column4: In Classical Irish the forms were i"
column7: "an" – "i/in" when the following sound was slender
column8: and "a/an" when the following sound was broad. In both Irish and Scottish

column4: In Irish, gaaire for a government minister
gaBruíon (formerly gabruighean) in Irish means fighting"
column5: "quarrelling." gdCainnt in Scottish Gaelic is used as a noun only
column7: except in Arran where it is also a verb[9]

column5: A number of words are used in both languages for ocean" and "sea"
column7: an fharraige. gaCaladh or gacala (also in the compound "calafort" < "cala-phort") are commonly used in Irish for "harbour"."

column5: gaBreatain (Britain) is the same in both. The Scottish Gaelic equivalent for Wales is gdA' Chuimrigh, a Gaelicisation of an Anglicisation of the Welsh cyCymru. The Irish for Brittany is gaAn Bhriotáin from Latin Britannia"."
gaSiubhail means walk" or "stroll" in Scottish Gaelic
column6: but is also a euphemism for death"
